total_impedance_ori_txt: R1 and Re0 connected in series so Rd0=R1+Re0=2Ohm
R5 and Rd0 connected in parallel so Rc0=R5*Rd0/(R5+Rd0)=1.33Ohm
Rc0 and R4 connected in series so Rb0=Rc0+R4=2.33Ohm
R2 and Rb0 connected in series so Ra0=R2+Rb0=3.33Ohm
total_impedance_txt: R1 and R3 connected in series so Rd0=R1+R3=2Ohm
R5 and Rd0 connected in parallel so Rc0=R5*Rd0/(R5+Rd0)=1.33Ohm
Rc0 and R4 connected in series so Rb0=Rc0+R4=2.33Ohm
R2 and Rb0 connected in series so Ra0=R2+Rb0=3.33Ohm

total_impedance_ori_txt: R4 and Re1 connected in series so Rd1=R4+Re1=2Ohm
R5 and Rd1 connected in parallel so Rc1=R5*Rd1/(R5+Rd1)=1.33Ohm
R3 and Rc1 connected in series so Rb1=R3+Rc1=2.33Ohm
Rb1 and R1 connected in series so Ra1=Rb1+R1=3.33Ohm
total_impedance_txt: R4 and R2 connected in series so Rd1=R4+R2=2Ohm
R5 and Rd1 connected in parallel so Rc1=R5*Rd1/(R5+Rd1)=1.33Ohm
R3 and Rc1 connected in series so Rb1=R3+Rc1=2.33Ohm
Rb1 and R1 connected in series so Ra1=Rb1+R1=3.33Ohm

request.text: What is the voltage on R1?

solution: We have more than one generator so we are using superposition to calculate voltages/currents.
>> Pass1 started ...
>> Gen processing: IS1 ...
This is a DC calculation
At first we calculate the total resistance between the generator nodes (IS1)
R1 and R3 connected in series so Rd0=R1+R3=2Ohm
R5 and Rd0 connected in parallel so Rc0=R5*Rd0/(R5+Rd0)=1.33Ohm
Rc0 and R4 connected in series so Rb0=Rc0+R4=2.33Ohm
R2 and Rb0 connected in series so Ra0=R2+Rb0=3.33Ohm
The total resistance is Ra0 = 3.33Ohm
Now we calculate the voltage on R1

We know that the voltage between IS1 nodes is 3.333333333333333V, because the generator current is Igen = 1A and the resistance between the generator nodes is Rtot = 3.33Ohm so the voltage between the generator nodes is Igen*Rtot = 3.333333333333333V
All voltage generators have been replaced with a short circuit.
All current generators except for IS1 have been replaced with an open circuit.
(1) The components R2,Rb0 connected in series.
(1) The voltage between this components starting and ending node is 3.33V.
(1) Rb0 is in the voltage divider so the voltage on Rb0 is Rb0/Ra0*3.33V = 2.33V.
(2) The components Rc0,R4 connected in series.
(2) The voltage between this components starting and ending node is 2.33V.
(2) Rc0 is in the voltage divider so the voltage on Rc0 is Rc0/Rb0*2.33V = 1.33V.
(3) The components R5,Rd0 connected in parallel. The voltage on Rd0 is 1.33V because the voltage on Rc0 is 1.33V
(4) The components R1,R3 connected in series.
(4) The voltage between this components starting and ending node is 1.33V.
(4) R1 is in the voltage divider so the voltage on R1 is R1/Rd0*1.33V = 667mV.
>> Pass2 started ...
>> Gen processing: VS1 ...
This is a DC calculation
At first we calculate the total resistance between the generator nodes (VS1)
R4 and R2 connected in series so Rd1=R4+R2=2Ohm
R5 and Rd1 connected in parallel so Rc1=R5*Rd1/(R5+Rd1)=1.33Ohm
R3 and Rc1 connected in series so Rb1=R3+Rc1=2.33Ohm
Rb1 and R1 connected in series so Ra1=Rb1+R1=3.33Ohm
The total resistance is Ra1 = 3.33Ohm
Now we calculate the voltage on R1
We know that the voltage between VS1 nodes is 6V.
All voltage generators except for VS1 have been replaced with a short circuit.
All current generators have been replaced with an open circuit.
(5) The components Rb1,R1 connected in series.
(5) The voltage between this components starting and ending node is 6V.
(5) R1 is in the voltage divider so the voltage on R1 is R1/Ra1*6V = 1.8V.
Now we are using superposition to calculate the voltage on R1
Let's summarize the calculations from the previous section.
When you see subtraction here it means that the original direction reversed.
'voltage on R1' = 667mV+1.8V = 2.47V
